claim: Have willingness-to-pay conversations before engineering; design the product around the price.
rationale: Most products fail from hope-based pricing. Flip sequence to market+price first, then design/build.

claim: How you charge can be the innovation; monetization model often matters more than price.
rationale: Michelin’s ton-kilometer model aligned revenue to value; bad models can sink good products.

claim: Feature Shock: overstuffed products become confusing, overpriced, and undervalued.
rationale: Fire Phone loaded unvalued features; internal brilliance over customer need = write-downs.

claim: Minivation: underpricing leaves huge profits on the table; success can mask under-monetization.
rationale: Cost-plus pricing on high-value components forfeits margin (e.g., priced at $0.85 instead of $5).

claim: Hidden Gem: great ideas languish or get given away free due to fear or blind spots.
rationale: Kodak invented digital camera but hid it; disruptive ideas can die from core-business protection.

claim: Undead: technically alive products with virtually no demand—answering questions nobody asked.
rationale: Segway/Google Glass hype without WTP created undead products; signals include delusional appeal claims.

claim: Segment by needs/value/WTP, not demographics or firm size.
rationale: Prince Charles vs. Ozzy: demographics mislead; WTP-based segments enable tailored offers.

claim: Classify features: Leaders (must-have), Fillers (nice), Killers (cause rejection). Remove Killers.
rationale: Killers valued by <20% and disliked by >20% add cost and repel buyers; classification varies by segment.

claim: Use Good/Better/Best with ≤25% choosing Good and ≥70% choosing Better/Best (compromise effect).
rationale: Too much value in entry tier blocks upsell; curated three-tier lineups lift sales and profit.

claim: Knee-jerk price cuts when sales lag erode profit and brand; hold price or trade for value.
rationale: Premature discounts signal low value and are hard to recover; require non-price actions first.

claim: Before any price decrease, force three non-pricing alternatives; if cutting, get something in return.
rationale: Prevents reflexive discounting and preserves margin; encourages creative value-adds.

claim: Porsche Cayenne: WTP research 4 years pre-launch; designed to validated price; became best-seller.
rationale: Included valued cup holders, excluded racing transmission; rescued Porsche finances.

claim: Gillette Guard: set target price (15 rupees) then engineered to hit it; won 60% India razor market in 2 years.
rationale: Ethnographic WTP research led to simpler 4-component design matching price/value.

claim: Michelin ton-km model aligned revenue to value, making it most profitable tire company by 2011.
rationale: Usage-based pricing captured value from longer-lasting tires instead of unit discounting.

claim: Amazon Fire Phone: feature shock and no WTP validation led to $170M write-down.
rationale: Gimmicky features, poor battery, overpriced for perceived value; inside-out development failed.
